item.title: Spotty Intelligence Prompts U.S. Caution in Assessing Jet Crash in Egypt
item.description: Intelligence gathered thus far is seen by American officials as inconclusive and claims of responsibility as less than credible.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: A Kenyan Runner Maps a Way Home
item.description: Kelvin Serem comes from a family of subsistence farmers in Kenya, but he won a scholarship to a private school in New Jersey in 2011 and now attends Lafayette College as a student-athlete, all while supporting a school he helped have built in his home village.
item.dc:creator: DAN BARRY
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kelvin Serem, at Lafayette College in Easton, Penn., where he runs track. Serem, 21, comes from a family of subsistence farmers in Kenya.

item.title: Though Not on Ballot, Narendra Modi Is at Center of Vote in India
item.description: The Indian prime minister has staked in his prestige on helping his party gain control in the populous but poor state of Bihar.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India delivered a speech at an election rally in Aurangabad, in the state of Bihar, last month.

item.title: Netanyahu May Try to Mend Fences in First U.S. Visit Since Iran Deal
item.description: The campaign by the prime minister and pro-Israel groups against the nuclear accord with Iran has left raw feelings.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Apology for Army Raid
item.description: President Juan Manuel Santos apologized for a 1985 raid on the Supreme Court in which nearly 100 people were killed after the building was taken over by guerrillas.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Rebels Used Mustard Gas
item.description: Insurgents used sulfur mustard in August, which probably resulted killed an infant, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: FIFA’s Sepp Blatter Being Treated for ‘Stress-Related’ Medical Issue
item.description: Blatter’s lawyer said the FIFA president was in a hospital for a ‘checkup’ but was expected to return home shortly.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Sepp Blattter has been prohibited from all soccer-related activities until he is cleared.

item.title: West Fears Burundi Is on Brink of Conflict
item.description: Western diplomats and analysts say Burundi could explode in violence when a deadline for opposition groups to disarm expires Saturday.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Keystone XL Decision by Obama Takes Weight Off Trudeau
item.description: The official Canadian position was support for the Keystone XL project, but the new prime minister appeared to be unenthusiastic about it.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Search Continues for Missing in Brazil Mine Disaster; Death Toll Uncertain
item.description: Rescue teams searched through mud and debris on Friday for people still missing from a village devastated by the collapse of two dams at a Brazilian mine owned by the world's largest mining company, BHP Billiton.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Rescue efforts continued Friday after a dam collapse on Thursday released mining sludge into Bento Rodrigues, a village in southeastern Brazil.

item.title: In Protesting Against Israel, Youth in Gaza Also Defy Hamas
item.description: The Islamist group, which governs Gaza, said it could not allow violence against Israel because it had agreed to a truce that ended last summer’s war.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Filling a Top Post, Netanyahu Reconsiders Nominee Who Insulted Obama
item.description: The prime minister’s choice, Ran Baratz, has come under fire over his suggestion that President Obama was anti-Semitic and that John Kerry had the intellect of a preteenager.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Ran Baratz, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's nominee for public diplomacy chief.

item.title: Open Source: Oxford Students Want Statue of Cecil Rhodes Removed
item.description: Student protesters rallied at Oxford University’s Oriel College, calling for the removal of a statue of Cecil Rhodes, a British imperialist.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot from the Facebook page of Ntokozo Sbo Qwabe, an organizer of protests at Oxford University against a statue of Cecil Rhodes, the British imperialist who left part of his fortune to the school.

item.title: Citing Climate Change, Obama Rejects Construction of Keystone XL Oil Pipeline
item.description: The president’s decision was a major victory for environmentalists and a bitter loss for the oil industry.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Environmental activists gathered on Friday outside the White House to thank the president.

item.title: Germany Considers Tightening the Rules for Syrian Refugees
item.description: The announcement followed weeks of mounting doubt about whether Germany has the capacity to handle almost 800,000 refugees who have arrived this year.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Resisting Bomb Theory, Egypt Finds Itself Increasingly Alone
item.description: As Britain, the United States and Russia take steps to protect their citizens, Egypt’s public statements recalled the 1999 crash of an EgyptAir flight near Nantucket.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A plane carrying remains on Friday in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: Opinion: The Return of London’s Fog
item.description: The city’s famous air pollution is coming back. So why won’t politicians do anything?
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE L. CORTON
item.media:description: 1932: A foggy day at Lincoln’s Inn, London.

item.title: Putin Suspends Flights From Russia to Egypt Amid Security Fears
item.description: Russia has until now played down the possibility of terrorism as the cause of Saturday’s jet crash in Egypt, the country’s most popular tourist destination.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Tourists going through security on Friday at the Sharm el Sheikh airport in Egypt.

item.title: Greenpeace India Says It Has Been Ordered to Dissolve
item.description: The environmental group said the authorities in the state of Tamil Nadu, where the group is registered, had accused it of falsifying financial documents.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Greenpeace activists participating in a vigil near the India Gate war memorial in New Delhi in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese State TV Masks Ma Ying-jeou’s Taiwan Flag Pin
item.description: Eagle-eye viewers in mainland China noticed a strange discoloration on the suit lapel of the president of Taiwan during a news report.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
